trustfund: TF029240-PHRD-ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT PROJECT,TF035370-KENYA - ENVIRONMENTAL PROJECT,TF025390-PRIVATE SECTOR DEVELOPMENT

abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the project outcome was
            unsatisfactory. However results were mixed, for although
            private sector strengthening, produced outputs in terms of
            relevant outcome indicators, the quality of these outcomes
            was inadequate. Hence, sustainability is rated unlikely,
            though institutional development impacts are modest.
            Furthermore, while the performance of the borrower is
            unsatisfactory, based on the weak preparation efforts
            stemming from the lack of consensus within the Government,
            the Bank performance is rated satisfactory, not only because
            of sound project preparation, and supervision, but because
            of its responsiveness to, and understanding of the
            Government's concerns. Two main lessons are learned
            from this project. 1) New laws, and regulations are not
            sufficient to produce effective policy changes, particularly
            when political powers, will not enforce them. The
            Government's commitment to financial reforms was
            largely subdued, illustrated in the form of delays in
            submitting, and approving new banking legislation,
            aggravated by the reluctance to apply legislation timely,
            and consistently. 2) Effective strengthening of the
            financial sector, legal, and regulatory framework should
            precede any credit line operation, not merely accompany it,
            and, credit lines should not use public banks as financial
            intermediaries. The project demonstrates the high risks
            posed by a credit line operation, in a country with a weak
            banking system, poor regulatory framework, and thriving
            political influences.
